bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Loew's Incorporated, March 12, 1938

div1.p: Moran grants permission to use his name in the film “Yellow Jack.” He includes the names of other yellow fever volunteers.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Loew's Incorporated, March 12, 1938
div1.opener:
Havana, Cuba, March 12, 1938.
Loew's Incorporated,
1540 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Sirs:
div1.p:
I am informed by your Mr. William D. Kelly that you are
planning to make a “Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer” motion picture that will
be adapted, with some changes, from the play “YELLOW JACK”, written
by Sidney Howard and Paul DeKruif, and that you would like to give
me recognition for the part I played in the yellow fever experiments
by using my actual name, toward the end of the picture, under a
caption which will read substantially as follows:
“Yellow Jack celebrates what these men did, rather
then what they were. That their heroism, however,
should not go unrecorded, their true names are here
given:
ROBERT P. COOKE
LEVI E. FOLK
WARREN G. JERNEGAN
JOHN R. KISSINGER
JOHN J. MORAN”
it being your present intention to so use my name and as many of
the above names as you can obtain written permission to use. I
hereby grant you permission to so use my name in this picture.

I also understand that you plan to have characters in
this picture portraying men who are there shown as offering
themselves for the yellow fever experiments. The foregoing is
also agreeable to me, attaching no conditions to my permission
or consent.

I also understand that you must know definitely at this
time as to the status of this matter, because after production of
the picture is begun it will be impossible to make changes. There-
fore, I agree that this consent is not to be withdrawn.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, John J. Moran. My address:
John J. Moran,
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.,
455-457 Avenida Menocal (New numbers)
Havana, Cuba.
